key_points: Donald Rumsfeld, former U.S. Defense Secretary and architect of the Iraq war, died at 88.
Rumsfeld served as U.S. Defense Secretary twice, under Presidents Gerald Ford and George W. Bush.
He played a crucial role in the Iraq War, justifying the invasion with claims of weapons of mass destruction that were never found.
Rumsfeld's tenure saw significant controversy, including the Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal.
He authorized harsh interrogation techniques, drawing international condemnation for treatment of detainees.
Rumsfeld was a close ally of Vice President Dick Cheney but faced criticism for his handling of the Iraq war.
President Bush replaced Rumsfeld in November 2006 amid diminishing support for the Iraq War.
Critics blamed Rumsfeld for strategic errors in Iraq and Afghanistan, contributing to protracted conflicts.
Rumsfeld's management style and decisions faced criticism for the instability and violence in post-invasion Iraq.
Beyond his government roles, Rumsfeld was a successful businessman and served in various capacities including as a Navy pilot and U.S. NATO ambassador.
